questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes. X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the diagnosis of this patient: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints;

B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthritis. In the involvement of spine & pelvis in psoriatic arthritis, the patient experiences extreme back/neck pain, stiffness in back/neck that improves on moving around. The stiffness worsens by a period of rest. There is difficulty in bending or moving the back. The patient also complaints of fatigue. The x-ray shows asymmetric paravertebral ossification, thicker & larger syndesmophytes than ankylosing spondylitis. Occasionally, there are incomplete non-marginal syndesmophytes similar to AS.

 

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. The spine is the second most commonly affected site (53%), after the pelvis (70%). The lumbar spine and more commonly the L4 and L5 levels are the most frequently involved sites. Involvement of the atlanto-axial region is very rare. The vertebral body is almost always involved with a portion of the neural arch. The radiological appearance is characterised by an increase in the antero-posterior and lateral vertebral dimensions. The height of the vertebra is unchanged. The vertebral end-plates are subchondral condensations of trabecular bone and do not represent true bony cortex, i.e. there is no periosteum/endosteum interface at the caudal/cranial aspect of a normal vertebra. The “early” radiographic appearance of vertebral body is thickening and hypertrophy of the trabecular bone, parallel to the end plates. Progression of the sclerotic phase in the spine leads to “ivory vertebra”, due to an increase in the density of the vertebral body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes, along with the bamboo spine appearance in the spine x-ray are diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the OPD with a painless, very slowly growing mass of the right third finger. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enchondroma

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.

 

 

  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment is by extended curettage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Osteoclastoma is located at the epiphysis. The most common location is distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Patient presents with swelling and vague pain. Radiographic examination reveals bony swelling, eccentrically located at the end of the bone and soap bubble appearance on X-ray. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex, however, intraarticular extension is rare as the subchondral bone usually remains intact. Treatment is done by extended curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – the procedure of choice. 

 

 

Option D. Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone. It is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It is thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule. X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur. Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap, a result of development malformation. An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity. Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally. Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation, fracture through stalk or pedunculated (narrow based) lesion, sarcomatous change and Impingement of neighbouring structure, e.g. nerve, vessel, etc. Treatment: en bloc resection – extra-periosteal resection

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enchondromas as painless, very slowly growing masses that commonly affect the short bones of the hand.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone 

 

SALTER HARRIS CLASSIFICATION 

  • The arrangement of cells of the physis is in layers or zones. 
  • These layers include the reserve, proliferative and hypertrophic zones. 
  • The reserve zone serves as the storage area for lipids, proteoglycans, and glycogen for growth and matrix production later. 
  • The proliferative zone has the highest rate of extracellular matrix production and accounts for the most abundant longitudinal growth. 
  • The hypertrophic zone has three phases: 
    • Maturation allows for preparation for calcification
    • Degenerative further prepare the matrix
    • Provisional calcification zone is where chondrocyte death occurs, allowing for calcium release. 
  • Physeal fractures most commonly occur in the zone of provisional calcification, as it is the weakest in response to shearing stress. 
  • The physis is weaker than ligaments or periosteum in children, causing injury to the growth plate before other structures. 
  • Zones of physis:

 

 

 

  • Salter and Harris described two major types of epiphyseal plates: the pressure epiphysis and the traction epiphysis. 
  • Pressure epiphyses provide longitudinal growth, at the end of long bones, are intra-articular, and bear weight. 
  • Traction epiphyses provide appositional growth, at the origin or insertion of muscles, are extra-articular, and do not bear weight. 
  • Their classification focuses on injuries at pressure epiphyses. 
  • They recognized that physeal fractures consistently occur through the same histologic plane called the zone of provisional calcification. 
  • This zone, located in the zone of hypertrophy, represents a transitional point between calcified and non-calcified extracellular matrix proteins, making it weaker than its surrounding osseous-ligamentous structures, and therefore more susceptible to injury.

 

 

  • In type I injury, there is slip of epiphysis with damage to the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting zone: It is affected in storage disorders like Gaucher’s disease. 

 

Option B. Proliferative zone: It is affected in growth hormone defects like Larsen’s syndrome. 

 

Option D. Zone of provisional calcification: It is affected in mineralization defects like rickets. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. 
  • It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. 
  • Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: A patient who used to workout regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS

 

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) is the cellular death of components of bone due to impaired blood supply.
  • It affects anterolateral aspect of femoral head.
  • Etiopathogenesis: Idiopathic (most common) – called as Chandeliers disease.
  • Causes:

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Age 20-50 years with slight male preponderance (Young Male).
    • Bilateral in 50% of idiopathic cases, and 80% of steroid-induced cases.
    • Decreased range of motion especially internal rotation followed by abduction – characteristic feature
    • A characteristic sign is a tendency for hip to twist into external rotation during passive flexion - ‘Sectoral sign’ – with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed, it is grossly restricted – due to a sector of femoral head being involved in AVN.
    • X-rays Sclerosed area shows area of necrosis; Crescent sign – Crescentric defect in subchondral area.

 

 

  • MRI is the investigation of choice – Double line sign is seen.
  • T1: Reduced intensity or irregular outline of head.
  • T2: High signal intensity called as double line sign.

 

 

  • Classification system:
    • University at Pennsylvania system:
      • Mild AVN: < 15% of Femoral head involved
      • Moderate AVN: 15-30% of Femoral head involved
      • Severe AVN: >30% of Femoral head involved
         
  • Treatment:
    • Early stages: protected weight-bearing.
    • Pre-collapse stage: Core decompression to decrease intraosseous pressure in femoral head (Normal Intraosseous pressure = 10-20 mm Hg; 3-4 times in AVN). Drill holes are made in femoral head. This procedure also opens the channels for vascular ingrowths and it is also supplemented with bone grafting (Vascular or nonvascular) or electrical stimulation or bone morphogenic proteins.

 

 

  • Muscle Pedicle graft: Quadratus femoris (Meyers graft)/Tensor fascia lata graft (Joshi’s graft) can be fixed in femoral head to augment vascularity.

 

 

  • Rotational osteotomy: To get the intact part of femoral head in acetabulum weight-bearing area (anterolateral aspect of femur head) this is an extensive procedure requiring vascular repair along with it.

 

 

  • Arthritis/Collapse of femoral head: Total hip replacement one of the very commonly done procedure as most patients present at stage of arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB of hip. Initial focus is in the acetabulum. The majority of cases of hip TB presents as painful, restricted movements of the hip, and a limp. It is secondary to primary pathology in lungs, lymph nodes or any of the viscera. Disease usually starts during first three decades. Depending upon the extent of involvement, there can be deformity, shortening of the limb, swelling, pathological dislocations, and sinuses.

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum

 

 

Stage of arthritis

 

Treatment involved Girdlestone excision arthroplasty/arthrodesis/THR.

 

 

Stage I and II are treated with ATT and traction. If required, joint debridement/synovectomy can be done. Stage III, IV and V are treated with ATT and joint replacement/arthrodesis/osteotomy/excision arthroplasty.

 

Option C. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures of the femoral neck put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing ability of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. The patient will complain of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. MRI is more sensitive (100% sensitivity) and specific for diagnosis.

 

 

 

 

Garden’s classification

 

Treatment is done by closed reduction and internal fixation in age < 65 years. In age > 65 years, hemiarthroplasty is done if there is a pre-existing arthritis. If there is no pre-existing arthritis, total hip replacement is done.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Often referred to as "soft bone disease," is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by the inadequate mineralization of bone tissue. There is adult onset of bone softening and muscle weakness. This condition results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, weakening and softening bones. Symptoms are non-specific and may include low back and thigh pain, proximal muscle weakness and wasting; Myalgia and arthralgia; Muscle spasms; waddling gait; Spinal, limb, or pelvic deformities; Aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing; Increased falls; Hypocalcemic seizures or tetany. Triradiate pelvis, protrusion acetabular (acetabulum protrudes into pelvis due to bone softening. When bilateral, it is called as Otto Pelvis), pseudofracture are seen on x-ray. There is waddling gait due to muscular weakness.

 

 

A. Triradiate pelvis; B. Protrusio acetabuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip.
  • Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated her by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, her forearm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulled elbow

 

  • History of traction on elbow with forearm pronated is classical of pulled elbow.

 

PULLED ELBOW/NURSE MAID’S ELBOW

 

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

 

 

  • Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Maximum incidence in 1-4 years of age group.
    • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
    • X-rays are normal.
  • Treatment:
    • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90° and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anaesthesia. 
    • Immobilization is not necessary.
    • Supination is a gravity-assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of elbow. Elbow Dislocations in the pediatric population usually occur in older children (10-15 years) and can be associated with elbow fractures such as medial epicondyle fractures. Male: female = 3:1. Very rare in younger children < 3 years old. Mechanism of injury is fall on an outstretched hand. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow, attempts at motion are painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiographs shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship. Treatment is usually closed reduction and brief immobilization for 1-2 weeks. 

 

 

Option C. Fracture head of radius. Radial head fractures are common injuries and may occur in association with dislocation of the elbow. In children, radial neck fractures are more common than radial head fractures. Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity. It may lead to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint, weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radioulnar joint with heavy activities, and may produce cubitus valgus deformity.

 

 

Option D. Fracture coronoid process. Coronoid Fractures are traumatic elbow fractures that are generally pathognomonic for an episode of elbow instability. The patient presents with elbow deformity & swelling, elbow/forearm/wrist pain. On inspection & palpation, there is varus or valgus deformity, ecchymosis & swelling, and diffuse tenderness. The treatment involves brief immobilization, followed by early range of motion. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of traction on elbow with forearm in pronation in a child < 4 years of age is a classical feature of pulled elbow.

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained an open fracture of femur which was operated and stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rail fixator

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin.
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound.
  • Phalanges followed by tibia is the most common site.
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson

 

 

  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound.
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis.
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used.
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection.
  • In general, an increase in Gustillo grade is associated with an increase in infection risk.
  • External Fixation:
    • In external fixation the fixation device is external to skin-external fixator or Ilizarov fixator.
    • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.
    • Open fracture is one of the most common cause for segmental loss of bone.
    • For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.
    • The Rail Fixator is designed for bone transport for reconstructing bone loss following open fracture and sequestrectomy following osteomyelitis. It provides correction through bone transport, compression-distraction and bifocal lengthening. 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. K-nail. Femoral shaft fractures are one of the commonest high energy fractures, and intramedullary nailing is the gold standard management of these fractures. Intramedullary fixation is considered superior to plate fixation because of lower rates of infection, early weight-bearing, and lesser chances of non-union. Unlocked Kuntscher nail (K-nail) should only be used for isthmic femoral shaft fractures. The main drawback of K-nail for use in other types of femoral shaft fracture was lack of rotational stability. Nowadays, interlocking intramedullary nail is used for almost all types of femoral shaft fractures because of better rotational stability.

 

 

Option C. Ilizarov fixator. Ilizarov fixator is an effective treatment modality of open comminuted femur fractures with high union rate, adequate alignment and satisfactory functional outcomes. Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV. For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.

 

 

Option D. Proximal femoral nail. The proximal femoral nail (PFN) is an osteosynthetic implant is used to treat proximal femoral fractures in the trochanter area with a closed intramedullary fixation method. It consists of a funnel-shaped intramedullary nail with slight bending to reflect proximal femoral diaphyseal trochanteric morphology. It has two proximal openings, a larger one distally for a large femoral neck lag screw and a smaller one immediately above for a smaller anti-rotation screw/pin. There are small holes at the distal end of the nail for locking screws.  It can be combined with a wire cerclage with an open reduction for additional stability in complicated subtrochanteric fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixator shown in the image in the question is a Rail Fixator, used to treat open fractures to fill the bone gap.

questions.text: A young man, aged 25, arrived with complaints of being unable to bend the distal interphalangeal joint of his 4th and 5th fingers. Additionally, he faced difficulty in gripping a piece of paper between his fingers. Where is the probable location of the injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

  • The given clinical scenario depicts paralysis of medial 2 lumbricals and palmar interossei which are supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • Ulnar nerve lies behind medial epicondyle, marked as C in the given image.
  • Ulnar nerve supplies Flexor carpi ulnaris & medial half of flexor digitorum profundus in forearm and in hand, it gives motor supply to hypothenar muscles, adductor pollicis, all interossei and medial two lumbricals.

 

ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  1. High ulnar nerve palsy (Injury proximal to elbow): Paralysis of all muscles supplied ulnar nerve in forearm and hand. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.
  2. Low ulnar nerve palsy (Injury distal one third of forearm): Sparing of forearm muscles, Paralysis of hand muscles. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The structure marked as A is the deltoid tuberosity. Injury to this part is rare. Its superficial location places it at a risk of trauma, fracture, and sequestration.

 

Option B. The structure marked as B is the lateral epicondyle. The lateral epicondyle is usually involved in the lateral epicondylitis or tennis elbow i.e., the overuse injury secondary to the eccentric overload of the common extensor tendon at the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) tendon.

 

Option D. The structure marked as D is the anatomical neck of humerus. Here, the shoulder joint capsule is attached. Injury to this part is highly uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4th and 5th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.

questions.text: Which tendons are involved in the test shown below?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) APL and EPB

 

  • Finkelstein test has been shown which helps to diagnose de Quervain’s tenosynovitis (Inflammation of Abductor Pollicis Longus and Extensor Pollicis brevis).

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic.
  • The examiner places patients’ thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction.
  • In positive test, this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the thumb left free is relatively painless.

 

 

  • Differential diagnosis includes scaphoid non-union, arthritis at the base of thumb and intersection syndrome.
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons are inflamed in the condition called De Quervain Tenosynovitis.
  • The diagnostic special test for the condition is called Finkelstein Test as shown in the image in the question.

choices.text: Commonly presents in the 20-40 years age group
Matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells
Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor
It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis

questions.text: About giant-cell tumor, all are true except:(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. 
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
    • The proliferative component of a giant cell tumor (GCT) is primarily made up of the mononuclear stromal cells, which are mesenchymal in origin.
    • These stromal cells are the neoplastic (tumor-forming) cells of GCT and play a central role in tumor growth and aggressiveness.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. 
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. 
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of multinucleated giant cells (40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). 
  • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors commonly presents in the 20-40 years of age group. 
  • Microscopically, the matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells.
  • Osteoclast giant cells induce the proliferation of the monoculcear macrophage cells, increasing the mononuclear cell population. 
  • It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis in about 4% cases.

questions.text: Following is the x-ray of an 18-year-old boy who complains of fever, pain in the lower limb, local rise of temperature, and tenderness in the area shown. On investigation, he has increased ESR. What can be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ewing's sarcoma

 

  • This case presents a teenager (18-year-old) with symptoms of fever, pain, local rise in temperature, and tenderness in the lower limb, along with increased ESR are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Radiological features:
    • The first image shows a layered periosteal reaction (onion-skin appearance), which is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma.
    • The second and third images show a permeative pattern of bone destruction with a soft tissue mass, another hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Ewing's sarcoma typically affects children and adolescents (common in ages 10–20).
  • Symptoms include localized pain, swelling, fever, and elevated ESR, often mimicking infection like osteomyelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors typically arise in the reproductive organs (testes or ovaries) or occasionally outside these locations (extragonadal). It is not typically a primary bone tumor and doesn't fit the radiographic pattern.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and can cause fever, pain, and elevated ESR, mimicking the symptoms of this case. However, osteomyelitis is more likely to show a solid periosteal reaction or sequestra on x-ray. Osteomyelitis may look similar clinically but rarely shows onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is another malignant bone tumor that commonly presents with a sunburst appearance and Codman’s triangle on x-ray. However, osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis (the wide part at the ends of bones), particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia, rather than the diaphysis. It usually presents with pain and swelling but not systemic signs like fever and high ESR to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma typically presents in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents, with a onion skin periosteal reaction seen on x-ray.

questions.text: Which muscle is inserted on the lesser trochanter of the femur? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psoas major

 

  • Psoas major muscle is a paraspinal muscle located deep in the body.
  • It lays close to the spine on either side and extends distally to the brim of the lesser pelvis.
  • It acts to laterally flex the lumbar spine and assists with flexion and external rotation of the hip.
  • It is essential for correct standing or sitting lumbar posture, stability of the hip joint, and during walking and running.
  • The psoas muscle is one of the core muscles.
  • The psoas muscle contains superficial and deep parts.
  • Superficially, it originates along the lateral surface of the distal thoracic vertebrae and adjacent intervertebral discs.
  • The deeper portion originates at the first 4 lumbar vertebrae.
  • The fibres of the muscle converge from its wide origin as they descend on the posterior abdominal wall.
  • They cross the pelvic inlet to form a long tendon, which is joined within the pelvic region by fibres from the iliacus muscle, finally inserting into the lesser trochanter of the femur. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoas minor: The psoas minor muscle originates along the lateral aspect of the vertebral body of the 12th thoracic vertebrae and the 1st lumbar vertebrae, and the intervertebral disc between those two vertebrae. There are two psoas minors, one on each side of the spine. Distally, it blends with the iliopsoas fascia. It inserts into the pectineal line of the pubis (not always present).

 

 

Option C. Obturator internus: The obturator internus muscle originates from the inferior margin of the superior pubic ramus and from the pelvic surface of the obturator membrane. Its tendon exits the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen to insert onto the greater trochanter of the femur.

 

 

Option D. Piriformis: It originates from the anterior aspect of the sacrum at the level of S2-S4, sacrotuberous ligament, and periphery of the greater sciatic notch. It inserts on the superior and medial aspects of the greater trochanter.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Psoas Major muscle inserts at the lesser trochanter of the femur and is involved in flexing the hip joint.

questions.text: A patient after a roadside trauma presented to the trauma center. He has a severe pain in his left hip and, on examination the hip is exquisitely tender with restricted range of motion. The patient is lying in the posture seen below. Which of the following deformity is seen in the patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior dislocation of hip

 

ANTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.

 

 

FABER position of limb after dislocation

 

  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • It is less common than posterior dislocation
  • It is divided into various types according to the position assumed by the femoral head: 
    • Pubic
    • Obturator
    • Perineal
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture at the affected hip, with restriction of movement.
    • Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type).
       
  • Imaging Findings
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • An anterior dislocation usually can be reduced without surgery by pulling longitudinally on the thigh.
    • If the dislocation cannot be reduced by these maneuvers, open reduction is performed.
       
  • Complication: 
    • Avascular necrosis.
    • Because of their anterior relationship to the hip, the femoral vessels and nerve may be injured, especially with pubic dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior dislocation of hip. The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. It is more common (90%). The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed in motor accidents. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

In plain radiograph, the femoral head is out of the acetabulum.

 

 

The thigh is internally rotated so, the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken. In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. Open reduction may be required in cases where closed reduction fails, if there is intra-articular loose fragment, and if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Complications include injury to the sciatic nerve, avascular necrosis of the femoral head, osteoarthritis, myositis ossificans.

 

Option C. Inferior dislocation of hip. Inferior dislocation of hip or luxatio erecta femoris is the rarest among all types of hip dislocation. It can be caused by a severe trauma to the hip. Most of the reported cases involve the pediatric age group. There are two types of inferior hip dislocation; ischial type and obturator type. In the obturator type, when a force is applied to femur while the hip joint is in abduction and flexion, the femoral head dislocates anteriorly and inferiorly to the obturator foramen. In the ischial type, a force is applied to femur while hip and knee joints are in hyperflexion without abduction or external rotation. The femoral head dislocates inferiorly next to the ischium. The ischial type is more common than the obturator type.

 

 

Option D. Central dislocation of hip. A central dislocation involves the femoral head being forced downward. Acetabular fractures with central hip dislocation result from direct axial loading through the greater trochanter in abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Restricted hip range of motion with FABER deformity of the hip is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presents to emergency department with pain in right hip and is unable to walk. She gives a history of fall in bathroom. On examination, you observe that there is shortening of left lower limb and is externally rotated. There is no history of arthritis. X-ray of hip is given below. What will be the management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemiarthroplasty

 

  • Patient with shortening of limb with external rotation and given x-ray suggests that this is a case of fracture neck of femur.

 

FRACTURE NECK OF FEMUR

 

  • In a physiologically > 60-year-old patient and with no features of arthritis, a displaced fracture neck of femur is managed by Hemiarthroplasty.
  • Features of Fracture Neck of Femur:
    • External rotation of the leg with patella facing outwards.
    • Shortening of leg
    • Tenderness in groin
    • Painful hip movements
  • Classification for Fracture Neck of Femur:

 

 

 

  • Treatment of fracture neck of femur:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Closed reduction. Non-operative treatment is usually preferred in younger patients. But it has a very limited role in them. This method is reserved for the sickest patients whose surgical risks negate fixation benefits.

 

Option C. Total hip replacement. THR appears to provide superior functional outcomes as compared to hemiarthroplasty in selected active, elderly patients, however, the rate of risk of complications is higher with THR, including dislocation.

 

Option D. Osteotomy. Valgus intertrochanteric osteotomies are done in cases of non-union of femoral neck fractures in younger patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient with neck of femur fracture, hemiarthroplasty is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Fracture at which site in leg will cause failure of dorsiflexion of foot? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal fibular neck

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • Trauma to the proximal neck of fibula leads to injury of the common peroneal nerve as the nerve winds around the neck of fibula.
  • The CPN injury causes paralysis of muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, namely tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, EHL, peroneus tertius (deep peroneal nerve), peroneal longus and brevis (superficial peroneal nerve).
  • Paralysis of these muscles causes failure of foot dorsiflexion i.e., foot drop.

 

 

  • There is also sensory loss on the anterior and lateral sides of the leg, dorsum of the foot and toes, and medial side of the big toe.
  • Lateral border of the foot and lateral side of the little toe are unaffected (supplied by sural nerve, formed by tibial nerve).
  • Medial border of the foot and ball of big toe are also unaffected (supplied by saphenous nerve, branch of femoral nerve).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral malleolus: Fracture at the lateral malleolus is Danis-Weber type A fracture of the ankle. In this, there is fracture of the lateral malleolus distal to the syndesmosis. It is usually a stable fracture. It is generally below the tibial plafond, with an intact syndesmosis and deltoid ligament. This fracture does not cause any nerve injury; thus no ankle movement is affected. This fracture has a good prognosis with ankle secured in a splint or cast.

 

Option B. Proximal tibia: Fracture of proximal third of tibia is associated with anterior knee pain (cases operated with intramedullary nailing), non-union, malunion. No nerve is injured with this type of fracture.

 

Option D. Tibial shaft: Tibial shaft fractures rarely cause nerve injury. Surgical fixation of the fracture with plating puts the superficial peroneal nerve at risk. Saphenous nerve can be injured during placement of locking screws. Transient peroneal nerve palsy after closed nailing can cause EHL weakness and decreased sensation of first dorsal webspace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the proximal neck of fibula causes paralysis of dorsiflexion of the foot because around this portion, the common peroneal nerve winds, which supplies the dorsiflexors of the foot.

choices.text: Proximal and Lateral displacement of radius
Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius
Proximal and Lateral displacement of ulna
Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of fall on an outstretched hand presented in OPD with complaints of pain and swelling in the right wrist. On examination, you observe a dinner fork deformity can be noticed. What is the correct statement regarding this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius

 

  • Dinner fork deformity is a finding in Colle’s Fracture, in which Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius is seen.

 

 

COLLES FRACTURE

 

  • It is the fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction, most commonly occurring in the post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly females, as a result of fall on outstretched hand with wrist in extension.
  • It is one of the most common fractures in elderly.
  • 6 components of colle’s:
    • Dorsal tilt
    • Dorsal displacement
    • Impaction
    • Lateral tilt
    • Lateral displacement
    • Supination
  • Most of these fractures are successfully treated non-operatively with a cast applied in pronation, palmar angulation, and ulnar deviation – also called as Hand shaking cast.

 

 

  • If prolonged immobilization is required in extreme position, or if reduction is lost early in treatment, then closed reduction followed by percutaneous K-wire fixation is done.

 

 

 

  • Complications includes:
    • Joint stiffness: finger stiffness is most common
    • Malunion is the 2nd most complication, leading to dinner fork deformity
    • Sudeck’s osteodystrophy
    • Extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture
    • Carpal tunnel syndrome
    • Carpal instability
    • TFCC injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal and lateral displacement of radius. This is called as Smith’s fracture. It is the reverse of colle’s fracture, where there is proximal and ventral/lateral displacement of the radius. It is treated by closed reduction and immobilization in an above elbow cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dinner fork deformity is commonly seen in the colle’s fracture, which is the proximal and dorsal displacement of the radius after a fall on the outstretched hand. It is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females.

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

 

IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME

 

  • It is soft tissues entrapment.
  • Tendinitis of the rotator cuff is the major cause of a painful shoulder.
  • The rotator cuff consists of the tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis, and teres minor muscles, and inserts on the humeral tuberosity.
  • The supraspinatus tendon is the most often affected, probably because of its repeated impingement between the humeral head and the undersurface of the anterior third of the acromion and coracoacromial ligament above as well as the reduction in its blood supply that occurs with abduction of the arm. This phenomenon is described as impingement syndrome.
  • The process begins with edema and hemorrhage of the rotator cuff which evolves to fibrotic thickening and eventually to rotator cuff degeneration with tendon tears and bone spurs.
  • Subacromial bursitis also accompanies this syndrome.
  • Symptoms usually appear after injury or overuse, especially with activities involving elevation of the arm with some degree of forward flexion.
  • Impingement syndrome occurs in persons participating in baseball, tennis, swimming, or occupations that require repeated elevation of the arm.
  • Severe pain is experienced when the arm is actively abducted into an overhead position. The arc between 60° and 120° (mid-range abduction) is especially painful. This is also described as “painful arc syndrome”.
  • NSAIDs, local glucocorticoid injection, and physical therapy may relieve symptoms.
  • Surgical decompression of the subacromial space may be necessary in patient refractory to conservative treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initial abduction: Incorrect, as the pain typically does not start at the beginning of abduction but becomes noticeable as the arm reaches mid-range.

 

Option C. Full range of abduction: Incorrect, although the entire range might be uncomfortable, the specific "painful arc" is usually observed in the mid-range.

 

Option D. Overhead abduction: Incorrect, as the term "painful arc syndrome" specifically refers to pain experienced in the mid-range of abduction, not necessarily when the arm is fully overhead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. 

  • Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

  • Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. 

  • Diagnosis:

    • Laboratory studies may reveal an increased white blood cell count, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and an elevated C-reactive protein.

    • A needle aspirate may grossly resemble pus.

    • Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. 

 

 

  • The image provided in the question shows a tumor composed of numerous small, relatively uniform, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm. This is the classic "small round blue cell tumor" appearance, which is typical of Ewing sarcoma.

 

  • Markers/Cytogenetics:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22).

  • MIC2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y. This is a highly characteristic and almost universally positive marker for Ewing sarcoma. It is often used as the primary diagnostic marker.

  • Synaptophysin is more commonly associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but it can be focally positive in some Ewing sarcomas, reflecting its neuroectodermal origin. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma (NB) is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. It is classified as an embryonal neuroendocrine tumor, originating from neural crest progenitor cells. Hence, it can occur anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, including the superior cervical, paraspinal, and celiac ganglia; the majority arise in the adrenal glands. The most important biological marker is MYCN. Patients with the MYCN gene tend to have rapid progression of cancer and poor outcomes. Other biological markers linked to poor prognosis include lack of expression of glycoprotein CD 44, elevated levels of telomerase RNA, elevated levels of LDH, serum ferritin, and serum neuron-specific enolase. 90% patients have elevations in vanillyl mandelic acid and homovanillic acid in the urine. Histopathology reveal small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (in 10-15% cases), with clustering of cells in the connective tissue. 

 

 

Small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen, presenting as calcification. 

 

 

Codman’s triangle 

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text:
True statements about fracture shaft of femur: (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. More commonly in elderly.
  2. Easily managed with Gallow’s traction in elderly.
  3. Associated with pulmonary complications.
  4. Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. c & d are correct

 

FRACTURE SHAFT FEMUR

 

  • Men are more likely to sustain a fracture between the ages of 15 to 35, while women begin to show a steady increase starting at age 60.
  • Men are more likely to sustain fracture from automobile accidents or other high-energy mechanisms.
  • Women are more likely to sustain an fracture from ground-level falls.
  • Automobile accidents are more prevalent in the younger population, while ground-level falls are more common in the elderly population, which is attributed to osteoporosis.
  • Treatment:

 

 

a. Management Plan of Fracture Shaft Femur in Adults: 

  1. Interlock intramedullary nailing currently is considered to be the treatment of choice for most femoral shaft fractures.
  2. External fixator is used in open fractures (open injuries).
  3. Delayed union is treated by dynamization of nail (removal of proximal or distal screws or both) and bone grafting.
  4. Non-union is treated by exchange nailing (i.e. introduction of large diameter reamed interlocking nail) and bone grafting.

 

b. Management Plan in children:

  1. Gallow’s traction: < 2 years of age and traction weight < 2 kg of weight can be used.
  2. Immediate or early spica casting is the treatment of choice in children <5 years of age for femoral fractures with < 2–3 cm of initial shortening, and stable fracture pattern.
  3. Femoral fractures with > 2-3 cm of shortening or marked instability, high probability of slipping of reduction and tight thigh swelling in 6 months to 5 years age group, who cannot be reduced with immediate spica casting, require 3-10 days of skin or skeletal traction before casting.
  4. Fixation by enders intramedullary flexible rods and plating can be used in children with multiple trauma, head injury, vascular compromise, floating knee injuries or multiple fracture, preferably in children > 6 years of age.

 

  • Complications:
    • Postoperative complications include fat emboli syndrome, pulmonary embolism, infection, osteomyelitis, malunion, nonunion, and hip and knee pain.
    • Nerve injuries are common and can be due to positioning as well as iatrogenic injury. Pudendal nerve injuries occur from positioning patients with a perineal post. The sciatic nerve can suffer injury in retrograde nailing with excessive traction of the lower extremity or surgical instruments. 
    • Vascular injury to the DFA or SFA can occur after penetration with instruments or implants.
    • Intraoperative fractures may occur, especially of the greater trochanter, the knee.
    • Malrotation is one of the most significant complications. Malrotation of greater than 14 degrees from neutral can alter gait mechanics and efficiency. Patients cope better with internal than with external malalignment.
    • Nonunion is a failure of the fracture to heal or lack of signs of healing for six months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Femoral shaft fractures are more commonly seen in young males of age 15-35 years.
  • It is easily managed with intramedullary nailing in elderly.
  • It is most commonly associated with pulmonary complications like pulmonary embolism.
  • Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management in adult patients.

questions.text: Match the Eponym with their fractures.(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e

 

  • The correct description of the given fractures are:

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

1. Pilon’s fracture: It is the intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal tibia. It is also known as Plafond fracture, Tibia Plafond fracture, Distal Tibial Explosion fracture. The high energy axial compression force if the tibia acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.

 

 

2. Runner’s fracture: It is the fracture of lower end of the fibula. They are usually the stress fracture, commonly seen in runners.

 

 

3. Cotton’s fracture: It is the trimalleolar fracture in the ankle i.e., there is involvement of medial and lateral malleoli, and posterior aspect of the tibial plafond (also called as posterior malleolus). This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.

 

 

4. Chauffer’s fracture: It is an intra-articular oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius. It is sustained from a direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction of the wrist.

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

 

INTRAOSSEOUS THERAPY 

 

  • Intraosseous access is a rapid and effective method to deliver fluids, medications, and blood products directly into the bone marrow when intravenous access is difficult or impossible, especially in emergency situations.
  • Interosseous therapy is most commonly used in pediatric patients but can also be used in adults. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle or catheter through the skin and into the bone, typically in the tibia or humerus bones.
  • A needle is inserted at 90° to the medial surface of the tibia, and it is connected to a tube, suggesting fluid administration or aspiration.
  • Some common indications for IO therapy include:
    • Cardiac arrest or other life-threatening emergencies
    • Severe dehydration or shock
    • Patients with difficult venous access, such as obese or severely dehydrated patients or patients with vascular access issues due to scarring, burns, or other injuries.
    • Emergency situations such as during disasters or mass casualty incidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraosseous abscess drainage: A drainage procedure usually involves a larger incision or different type of instrument for effective drainage.


Option C. Diagnostic biopsy: A bone biopsy involves taking a tissue sample for pathological examination. While a needle is used, the setup with continuous tubing for fluid administration is not typical for a routine diagnostic biopsy.
 

Option D. Intraosseous cannulation for pain relief: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation is a rapid method to administer medications through the bone marrow cavity in a critically ill or an injured patient. The procedure is both safe and effective in children and adults. The preferred site for the creation of intraosseous (IO) access is usually the shin. A local anesthetic is injected into the shin. Next, a cannula is inserted into the shin until a popping sensation is felt. Once the attempt is successful, the cannula is connected to the intravenous (IV) infusion set, which is a collection of sterile devices designed to conduct fluids from the IV fluid container to a patient's venous system. Indications for IO access includes arrhythmias, severe haemorrhage, septic shock, respiratory failure, severe dehydration, diabetic ketoacidosis, and burns. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented in OPD with complaints of a gradual progressive swelling around his wrist for 2 months as shown below. A radiograph was taken. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoclastoma

 

  • Given presentation and an X-ray showing a lesion with soap bubble appearance points to a diagnosis of Osteoclastoma/Giant Cell Tumour.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s Sarcoma is a diaphyseal tumour mimics inflammation – redness, fever, swelling. Radiograph shows Onion-skin periosteal reaction. It is the most radiosensitive and chemosensitive tumor.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma is a radiation induced sarcoma. Characteristic findings are – Codman’s triangle; Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma is the commonest benign tumour of the bone. It is not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor typically appears in patient of 20-40 years of age. They are most commonly seen at the epiphyseal region of the long bone and also about the subchondral bone. Radiologically, the lesions are eccentrically located, purely lytic, expands/breaks through the cortex.

questions.text: The following sets of X-rays are suggestive of:(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity.
    • Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur.
    • Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
    • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
       
  • Spine radiograph:
    • Loss of lumbar lordosis (Straightening).
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.
    • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
    • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
    • Erosions of anterior corners of vertebral body causing squaring of vertebral body.
    • Bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) with vertical orientation bridging vertebral bodies are seen. Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. It is the osteoclast that appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity. Long bone X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen. Skull X-ray reveal “cotton wool” or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic area. Vertebral cortical thickening at superior and inferior end plates creates a picture frame vertebrae and diffuse sclerosis causing ivory vertebrae. Pelvic radiograph shows sclerotic iliopectineal line (Brim sign), fusion or disruption of sacroiliac joints, etc.

 

 

Blade of grass appearance

 

 

 

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism maybe primary (due to adenoma or hyperplasia), secondary (due to persistent hypocalcemia) or tertiary (when secondary hyperplasia leads to autonomous overactivity). Parathyroid adenoma is most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. It presents with subperiosteal resorption, and replacement of endosteal cavitation marrow by vascular granulation and fibrous tissue (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Classical and pathognomic feature of hyperparathyroidism is subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges on radial aspect. Clinical features are Abdominal groans (dyspepsia), psychic moans, renal stones and weak bones (Groans, moans, stones and Bones). Hyperparathyroidism causes diffuse rarefaction of bone (osteopenia) and osteitis fibrosa cystica. Radiological Features includes subperiosteal resorption of terminal tufts of phalanges, lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis, loss of lamina dura (i.e. thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as thin white line, is resorbed), irregular, diffuse rarefaction of bones, i.e. generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae, brown tumor, salt pepper appearance of skull.

 

 

 

Resorption of lamina dura

 

 

Salt-pepper skull

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The radiographic images given the question shows:

 

A. Bamboo spine

 

B. Sacroiliitis

 

C. Loss of lumbar lordosis

 

D. Dagger’s sign

 

These features are characteristic of Ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to OPD with the following presentation. How will you manage the patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manipulation and cast

 

  • The deformity shown is Congenital Talipes Equino Varus (CTEV) and for < 1-year-old baby, management will be manipulation and cast.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posteromedial soft tissue release. It is best done in children of 1-3 years of age with CTEV. In children > 3 years of age, lateral column shortening procedures are often done in conjunction with posteromedial soft tissue release.

 

Option C. Triple arthrodesis. This procedure is done in age > 10 years in recurrent/persistent clubfoot cases (chronic cases), when foot growth is complete & bones are ossified to achieve good fusion.

 

Option D. Evan’s procedure. Evan-Dilwyn procedure is done at the age of 3-8 years. It involves resection & fusion of calcaneocuboid joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In children with CTEV of age group less than 1 year, the mainstay treatment done is manipulation and cast in the order of correction of cavus – adduction – varus – equinus (C-AV-E).
  • The fulcrum while manipulation lies at the head of talus.
  • The duration of this treatment method is for 6-8 weeks.

choices.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints
Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient’s hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rheumatoid arthritis

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis: Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
      • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    1. Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    2. Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint, upper cervical spine
    3. Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
      • Usually, DIP is not involved. It is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
      • Lumbar spine is spared.
      • Others: The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children. Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis in patients of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heberden's nodes on pre-existing osteoarthritis. Heberden’s nad Bouchard’s nodes are firm swellings over the superolateral and dorsal aspects of DIP and PIP joints respectively. Lateral view of the x-ray of the hand reveals large exostoses arising from the proximal ends of the distal phalanges in the attachment of extensor and flexor tendons. They may begin as small, round, fluctuant, tender mass, a little to one side of the dorsum of the joint.

 

 

 

Option C. Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints. Tenosynovitis is quite common, but it is generally not a striking or isolated clinical complaint. The most common sites are the extensor tendon sheaths on the dorsum of the hand, the extensor sheaths over the dorsum of the foot, and those of the posterior tibial tendon and the peroneus longus and brevis tendons. If tenosynovitis is very prominent, Blau syndrome should be considered. Triggering or loss of extension of the fingers may result from a stenosing synovitis of the flexor tendon sheaths.

 

 

Option D. Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome. CRPS is characterized by a chronic neurological disorder involving upper or lower limbs after any type of injury or surgery. In some cases, it occurs spontaneously. Sensory and autonomic disturbances are the main features of this syndrome (allodynia or hyperalgesia, edema, changes in skin blood flow or abnormal sudomotor activity) and are disproportionate to the starting event. The underlying mechanism is still unknown. Multiple mechanisms considered to play a role in the generation and maintenance of CRPS includes biofeedback from autonomic nervous system, alterations of central nervous system, neurogenic inflammation and immunological mechanisms. There is no specific diagnostic test for CRPS. History, clinical examination, symptoms and signs of the patient are the main aspects to be considered for a correct diagnosis. CRPS does not have a pathognomonic sign. The key symptom is prolonged pain that may be constant and disproportionate to the initial injury. The characteristics of the pain are continuous, spontaneous or episodic. Patients frequently described this symptom as burning. The distal part of the limb is the most common area and the typical clinical manifestations are red skin, pain, and swelling. Symptoms may change over time and vary from patient to patient. Over time the injured limb can became pale, cold and in addition muscle spasm and tightening can appear. This condition is often irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image and the symptoms in a female of pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand, morning stiffness with problem in squatting is clinical for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following childhood injuries will lead to a fish tail injury? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distal humerus in children

 

  • Fishtail deformity of the distal humerus is a rare delayed complication of distal humeral fractures in children characterized by a contour abnormality of the distal humerus.
  • It results from a non-developing or underdeveloped lateral trochlea.

 

 

  • It has been described after a variety of distal humeral fractures in early childhood, most commonly after supracondylar fractures, or lateral Condyle fractures.
  • If identified in a young child, surgical closure of the medial and lateral portion of the physis may prevent the deformity from progressing and would not cause significant additional humeral length discrepancy.
  • Whilst initially presumed to be a benign condition, long-term follow-up suggests that patients with fishtail deformity are prone to:
    • Functional impairment
    • Ongoing pain
    • Development of early osteoarthrosis

 

Option B. Distal radius. Distal Radius Fractures are the most common site of pediatric forearm fractures and generally occur as a result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the wrist extended. Metaphyseal fractures can be at the volar apex (colle’s fracture) or dorsal apex (Smith’s fracture) or incomplete (torus/buckle fracture). Diaphyseal fracture may involve both bone fracture, plastic deformation or greenstick fracture. Fracture with dislocation includes monteggia and galeazzi fractures.

 

 

Option D. Distal femur. Distal femur fractures in children can have various fracture patterns, including supracondylar fractures, or fractures of any pattern from the Salter-Harris classification.  Salter-Harris II fractures of the distal femur are the most common pattern in children. Even though distal femur fractures are relatively uncommon injuries, they can have significant implications for limb alignment and future growth. Distal femur fractures in children are typically related to trauma, such as falls, motor vehicle accidents, or contact sports. Patients have pain, swelling about the knee, deformity, and an inability to bear weight on the affected leg. Closed manipulation and casting is an option in displaced fractures, although they have significant potential for instability, which could lead to malunion. Internal fixation is the most commonly chosen treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fish tail deformity is a rare complication of distal humerus fracture in children.

choices.text: Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
Ulnar fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
Ulnar shaft fracture and disruption of superior radio-ulnar joint
Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseous membrane tear and radial shaft fracture

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly defines Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE

 

  • The combination of fracture of the distal third of the shaft of the radius and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, along with damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex, is called Galeazzi Fracture-dislocation.
  • It is the fracture of necessity.
  • A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.
  • Monteggia and Galeazzi Fractures:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

 

FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Treatment of femoral shaft fractures can be operative or non-operative.
  • Operative fixation with intramedullary nailing is the gold standard treatment.
  • Other operative techniques include plate osteosynthesis and external fixation.
  • Closed treatment with traction, splinting, and casting may be temporary treatment.

 

Intramedullary Nailing

 

  • Intramedullary nailing (IMN) is the gold standard of treatment for femoral shaft fractures.
  • Early treatment in a stable patient within 24-48 hours reduces the incidence of pulmonary complications, infection, and mortality.
