  • Delayed treatment increases pulmonary complications in up to 56% of patients compared to only 16% of patients treated early.
  • The insertion site of an IMN is outside the zone of injury, preserving the surrounding blood flow and retain the hematoma that contains beneficial bone growth factors.
  • It provides a strong and stable internal fixation that allows for early mobilization and weight-bearing, which is crucial for promoting healing and preventing complications.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure compared to other options like plate fixation, resulting in less tissue disruption and blood loss.
  • It helps in a faster recovery time and a quicker return to daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip Spica: This is a cast that extends from the waist to the toes and is not typically used for femoral shaft fractures due to the limited mobility it allows.

 

Option B. Above Knee Slab: An above-knee slab is a temporary cast that can be used for pain management and swelling reduction but doesn't provide enough stability for healing a fractured femoral shaft.

 

Option C. Above Knee Cast: Similar to an above-knee slab, a cast offers limited stability and wouldn't be suitable for the long-term treatment of this fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

questions.text: A young man had a fall on his outstretched hand, presented to the hospital with pain on the radial side of wrist and swelling in the anatomical snuff box. X-ray showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scaphoid fracture

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children.
  • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30.
  • Middle third (waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.
  • Salient Features:
    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.
    • A delay in diagnosis and treatment of this fracture may alter the prognosis for union.
    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possibe fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.
    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.
  • Radiological Investigations:
    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.
    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.
    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.
  • Management:
    • Non-displaced, stable scaphoid fractures: Scaphoid glass holding cast

 

  • Displaced, unstable scaphoid fractures: Headless screw (Herbert) is used
  • Complication: Non-union > Avascular necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans-scaphoid perilunate disruption fracture. Trans-scaphoid fracture-dislocation is an unusual traumatic injury mainly seen in young patients due to high energy trauma. These dislocations may be missed in 25% of cases. If it is neglected, it leads to progress of carpal instability and post-traumatic arthritis. The treatment aims at reducing dislocation, internally fixing fracture, and repairing ligament injuries. In the acute period, there is pain and swelling over the hand and wrist, and gross deformity of the wrist can be noted. Evidence of median nerve injury is common. Acute carpal tunnel syndrome is observed in about 25% of patients. Radiographs of the contralateral wrist for comparison can be helpful to confirm scapholunate widening, also called a ‘Terry Thomas sign.’

 

 

 

Terry Thomas Sign

 

Option C. Hook of hamate fracture. Hook of hamate fractures are rare, often missed injuries generally as a result of a direct blow to the hamate bone. It is most commonly seen in athletes. Mechanism of injury is a direct blow to the volar proximal palm. Ulnar-sided wrist pain is the most common complaint, hypothenar pain, pain with activities requiring tight grip. On examination, there is limited ulnar deviation and decreased grip strength. Diagnosis is confirmed with radiographic carpal tunnel view or CT scan. Treatment is either observation, surgical excision, or surgical fixation depending on the severity of the symptoms and activity demands of the patient.

 

 

Option D. Distal radius fracture. Distal radius fractures are the most common injury, resulting from fall on an outstretched hand. It is more common in older patients with osteoporosis due to fall. The patient presents with wrist pain, swelling, and deformity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray, mechanism of injury, and presenting complaints of the patient points towards the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cauda equina syndrome

 

CAUDA EQUINA SYNDROME

 

  • Cauda equina syndrome results from compression (squeezing) of the cauda equina – the sac of nerves and nerve roots at the base and just below the spinal cord in the lumbosacral spinal canal.
  • It is a rare but serious disorder, and a medical emergency.
  • The nerves of the cauda equina provide motor and sensory function to the legs and the bladder.
  • Compression of these nerves can interrupt their function, and the effects can be severe.
  • Causes:
    • Lumbar disc herniation (most common)
    • Trauma
    • Spinal tumor
    • Spinal stenosis
    • Infection
    • Vertebral fractures from osteoporosis
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe low back pain
    • Bladder dysfunction such as urinary retention or incontinence
    • Bowel incontinence
    • Muscle weakness or sensory loss in both legs
    • Loss of motor function in legs
    • Loss or reduction of reflexes
    • Saddle anesthesia (inability to feel anything in the body areas that would sit on a saddle)
  • Investigations:
    • Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging: The best method of imaging the spinal cord, nerve roots, intervertebral discs, and ligaments. Since these scans can detect damage or disease of soft tissue, MRIs are valuable in diagnosing the cause of cauda equina syndrome.
    • Myelogram: Procedure that involves injecting a liquid dye into the spinal column. These X-ray and CT images [usually performed with a computerized tomography (CT) scan] can show pressure on the cauda equina from herniated discs and other conditions.
  • Treatment:
    • Cauda equina syndrome is a potential surgical emergency and may require timely decompression surgery to reduce/remove the pressure on the nerve(s).
    • Undergoing early surgery seems to offer the best chance for improvement of sensory and muscle function as well as bowel and bladder function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pott’s spine. Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest symptom (1st symptom). Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for anterior elements is more significant as disease involves the vertebral body (paradiscal) anteriorly. Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier).

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma. Elderly with bone pains, increased ESR and hypercalcemia is multiple myeloma till proved otherwise. Bone pain is the most common complaint for patients with multiple myeloma. In contrast to most bone tumors, other systemic problems, such as weakness, weight loss, anemia, thrombocytopenia, peripheral neuropathy, hypercalcemia, or renal failure, frequently are present at the time of diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Symptoms usually are of short duration because of the aggressive nature of the disease. Pathological fractures are relatively common. The spine is the most common location followed by the ribs and pelvis.

 

Option D. Bone metastasis. The common symptoms include bone pain (frequent symptom), gradual in onset and described as a dull, boring pain that is worse at night. Bone metastases causing nerve root compression can present as radicular pain different from mechanical pain. As the vertebra is the most common site of metastasis, a significant complication includes spinal cord compression, which is an oncologic emergency. Metastatic spinal cord compression occurs either through pathological vertebral collapse or direct epidural extension. Patients may present initially with back pain. Limb weakness is the second most common symptom. Sensory symptoms include paresthesia and numbness at and below the level of cord compression. Autonomic dysfunction, including bowel and bladder incontinence and impotence, is typically a late presentation. In malignancy, hypercalcemia can be multifactorial and confers a poor prognosis overall. Osteolytic bone metastases are associated with 10-30% of the cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy due to enhanced osteoclastic bone resorption. Symptoms include nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, and mental status changes. Bone metastases cause bone destruction, increasing the risk for atraumatic fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presenting symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of cauda equine syndrome caused due to lumbar disc prolapse.

questions.text: Tom-Smith arthritis destroys: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral capital epiphysis

 

TOM SMITH ARTHRITIS

 

  • It is septic arthritis of hip in infants which destroy the cartilaginous femoral head rapidly and completely (chondrolysis).
  • It is caused by non-tuberculous bacteria.
  • This intra-articular infection in children peaks in first few years of life with 50% patients younger than 2 years of age.
  • Males affected more than females – 2:1 ratio
  • Hip joint is more commonly involved, followed by knee joint.
  • Risk factors:
    • Prematurity
    • Caesarean section
    • Treatment in NICU
    • Invasive procedures like umbilical/venous catheterization, heel puncture
       
  • Clinical features: 
    • Child presents with limp, unstable gait
    • Shortening of limb
    • Positive telescopy
    • Increased hip movements in all direction
    • Limb position – flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER)
    • Fever
    • Unable to bear weight
       
  • In 55% cases, no organism is identified.
    • Streptococcus is most commonly seen in neonates
    • Staphylococcus aureus is commonly seen in children over 2 years of age
    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is commonly seen in adolescents
       
  • Kocher criteria is used for diagnosis:
    • WBC > 12,000 cells/ml of serum
    • Inability to bear weight
    • Fever > 101.3°F
    • ESR > 40 mm/h
    • Additional criteria – CRP (Modified Kocher criteria)
       
  • Investigations:
    • Elevated WBC – leukopenia
    • Elevated ESR – may be normal in early course of infection
    • CRP may increase in first 6-8 hours of infection
    • Hip aspirate will show high WBC, low glucose levels, high lactic acid levels
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-ray may be normal in early stages
    • Shows widening of joint space, subluxation/dislocation

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • Non-operative: antibiotics
    • Operative: surgical irrigation and debridement followed by IV antibiotics
       
  • Prognosis:
    • Good prognosis
    • Delayed diagnosis may result in permanent joint damage and long-term disability. 
    • Long-term morbidity includes acetabular dysplasia, subluxation and dislocation, cartilage necrosis, limb length discrepancy, abnormal/premature closure of proximal femoral physis, ischemic necrosis, and complete destruction of femoral head
    • Poor prognostic factors:
      • Age < 6 months
      • Associated osteomyelitis
      • Delay of > 4 days until presentation
      • Hip joint involvement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetabular roof. Acetabular roof lesions are uncommon in children. If they occur, their cause can be eosinophilic granuloma, ewing’s sarcoma, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, metastases, and neuroblastoma.

 

 

Option C. Femoral neck. Femoral neck is affected in children in femoral neck fractures due to high-impact injuries, but this is uncommon. Benign bone tumors or tumor-like bone lesions in the femoral neck can also be the cause.

 

Option D. Greater trochanter. Avulsion fractures of greater trochanter are very rare in children. They can be secondary to gluteal muscle contraction, femoral neck fracture, hip dislocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tom smith arthritis or the septic arthritis in children, most commonly affects the femoral capital epiphysis.

questions.text: Match the following:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-5, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Madelung deformity involves distal radius.  It is the volar translation of the wrist. It is seen associated with Turner Syndrome.

 

 

B. Haglund deformity is the bony prominence over calcaneum and the overlying retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

C. Buttonhole deformity is the abnormal extension at distal interphalangeal joint and flexion at proximal interphalangeal joint and is seen with Rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

D. Gunstock deformity is seen in Cubitus varus. It is a complication frequently seen after untreated supracondylar fracture of humerus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the following image. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II

 

  • The Salter-Harris classification system is used to describe fractures involving the growth plate (physis) in children. 
  • The types range from I to V, with increasing severity:
    • Type I: Slip or separation of the growth plate.
    • Type II: Fracture that involves a part of the metaphysis and the growth plate. This is the most common type and is also known as the Thurston-Holland sign.
    • Type III: Fracture through the growth plate and epiphysis, involving the joint surface, causing epiphyseal split.
    • Type IV: Fracture through the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis.
    • Type V: Compression/crush injury to the growth plate with initially normal x-ray.

 

 

  • In the provided image, the fracture depicted involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis, which classifies it as a Type II injury.
  • Remember: 
    • MC type is Type II.
    • Location of Epiphyseal Injuries: When it comes to epiphyseal injuries, particularly in pediatric cases, these injuries typically occur through the zone of hypertrophy of the growth plate. This zone is one of the layers of the growth plate where chondrocytes mature and enlarge before the end of the bone lengthens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option Type I: Involves only the growth plate without extending into the metaphysis or epiphysis.

 

Option Type III: Involves the growth plate and the epiphysis, extending into the joint.

 

Option Type IV: Involves the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the Type II Salter-Harris physeal injury in children.
  • A Type II Salter-Harris fracture involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis and is the most common type of growth plate fracture.

choices.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

 

The given X-ray shows eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins with soap bubble appearance indicative of Giant cell tumour (GCT). Treatment of GCT includes Curettage or Excision with bone grafting.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells - a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.

 

Clinical Features

 

  • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
  • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
  • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.

 

Radiological Features

 

  • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.

 

Treatment

 

  • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
  • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective

 

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal 1/3rd

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Salient features: 

    • It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 

    • Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 

    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. 

    • Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.

  • Most common location:              

    • Adults and adolescents: Middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%). 

    • Children: Distal pole avulsion type fracture.

  • Pathogenesis of AVN:

    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 

    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.

    • Thus, the proximal third of the scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis (AVN) due to its precarious retrograde blood supply. 

    • Fracture in the waist (middle third) can disrupt this blood flow to the proximal fragment, leading to AVN.

  • Diagnosis: 

    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possible fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.

    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.

    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.

    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.

  • Treatment:

    • Nondisplaced, Stable Scaphoid Fractures: Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast.

    • Displaced, Unstable Scaphoid Fractures: Headless Screw (Herbert) is used

    • Complication: Non-union > Avascular Necrosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distal 1/3rd. Distal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid is a well vascularized area, so fracture to this part is often undisplaced or minimally displaced, thus they heal faster with conservative management. This portion of scaphoid is fractured in 10% of cases. AVN of this part occurs in 1% cases. 

 

Option B. Middle 1/3rd. Middle 1/3rd or the waist of scaphoid is most commonly fractures, accounting for 70% of cases. But the chances of AVN at this portion are around 20%. 

 

Option D. Scaphoid tubercle. Avulsion fracture of scaphoid tubercle are rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proximal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid have less chances of fracture (20%) but have higher chances of AVN (40%).

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Salmonella

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests acute osteomyelitis, and joint aspirate analysis is likely to reveal Salmonella as the causative pathogen.
  • The peripheral smear findings are indicative of sickle cell anemia, a hematological disorder characterized by a variety of complications such as acute painful episodes, priapism, stroke, leg ulcers, and acute chest syndrome (presenting as pneumonia-like symptoms with fever, cough, and hypoxia).
  • Acute osteomyelitis is an infection that affects the bone and is more commonly observed in children.
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for osteomyelitis, in patients with sickle cell anemia, Salmonella is often the causative agent.
  • Additionally, other bacteria such as Hemophilus influenzae, E. coli, Streptococcus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa can also cause the condition.
  • The infection can spread through the blood (hematogenous route) or through external sources like open fractures, iatrogenic interventions, or from nearby infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus. It is the most common organism to cause acute/subacute/chronic osteomyelitis, post-traumatic and post-surgical osteomyelitis in all age groups. It also causes acute pyogenic infections of spine.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type. Sternoclavicular joint is one of the rare location for hematogenous osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

questions.text: Which is the most common Osteoporotic fracture site?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebral fracture

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • The fractures that are most common (in decreasing order) are vertebral fracture > hip (neck femur) > lower end radius.
  • Most of the vertebral fractures are asymptomatic and are identified incidentally during radiograph for other purpose.
  • Few of these present as backache of varying degree.
  • Up to 70 years of age, the order of fracture incidence is vertebral > Colle’s.
  • Overall and in > 70 years of age, it is vertebral > Hip > Colle’s.
  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), codfish appearance and pencilling of vertebrae.

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra (Biconcave vertebra)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intertrochanteric fracture: These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. These patients are also typically older than patients who suffer femoral neck fractures. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism. The femur is the second most common site of fracture in the osteoporotic patients.

 

Option C. Femoral shaft fracture: Femoral shaft fractures can result from high or low energy mechanisms. The most common causes include automobile accidents, falls from heights, ground-level falls in individuals with osteoporosis, and gunshots. About 75% fractures are caused by high energy mechanisms. Other less common causes are atypical fractures from bisphosphonate use, pathologic fractures through a bone lesion, insufficiency fractures from osteoporosis, and stress fractures from overuse in athletes.

 

Option D. Subtrochanteric fracture: Subtrochanteric fractures are mainly seen in 2 patient populations: spiral fractures in osteoporotic patients and atypical insufficiency fractures that happen after no to low-energy trauma (e.g., patients who use long-term bisphosphate therapy). But femur involvement is the second common site in osteoporosis for fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.

questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. No sensory deficit was found. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior interosseous nerve

 

  • Flexion at interphalangeal joint of thumb is caused by flexor pollicis longus which is supplied by anterior interosseous nerve, a pure motor branch of median nerve.
  • It branches from the median nerve in the proximal forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres muscle to run deep along the interosseous membrane.
  • From proximal to distal, it innervates the flexor pollicus longus (FPL), the index and long fingers of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP), and the pronator quadratus (PQ).
  • AIN syndrome is an isolated palsy of these three muscles.
  • It manifests mostly as pain in the forearm accompanied by a characteristic weakness of the index finger and thumb pincer movement.
  • Many cases of AIN syndrome arise secondary to transient neuritis, although nerve compression and trauma are known etiologies as well. 
  • Supracondylar humerus fracture is also a common cause of AIN injury.
  • The most common site of AIN entrapment/compression is the tendinous edge of the deep head of the pronator teres muscle. 
  • True AIN syndrome presentation will present with motor deficits only. 
  • No sensory changes appreciated. There are no numbness, tingling, or sensory deficits.
  • The patient will complain of having difficulty bringing the distal phalanx of the thumb and index finger together.
  • On a physical examination, the pinch grip test is positive. Rather than making the "OK" sign, the patient will clap the sheet between the index finger and an extended thumb.

 

 

  • The patient may also complain of having difficulty forming a fist or the inability to button their shirts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. The effect of trauma on the median nerve depends on the injury site and may involve the palm, forearm, arm, or axilla. The damage to the nerve can lead to motor, sensory, and vasomotor loss. Most injuries to the median nerve occur at the wrist. Traumatic injuries to the median nerve at the wrist can be due to wrist fractures. Nerve damage can range from compression to nerve contusion. On the wrist, the median nerve is exposed to cutting and penetrating injuries. The signs and symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome include thenar weakness, numbness in the radial 3 ½  fingers, and paresthesias, burning-like pain in the distribution of the median nerve. Symptoms can mimic the effects of an injury to the C6, C7 nerve roots. Symptoms are typically worse at night and awaken patients from sleep. There is no triceps or weakness in wrist extension. Carpal tunnel is also distinguishable with the Tinel and Phalen tests. A positive Tinel sign and positive Phalen maneuver are indicative of carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 

Phalen’s Test for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

 

Option B. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve. The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve is a terminal branch of the ulnar nerve. It supplies the palmaris brevis and the skin on the ulnar side of the hand. The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow and the wrist. Mechanism of injury includes local trauma, nerve impingement, lacerations at the wrist and Guyon canal cyst. Characteristic signs of injury to the ulnar nerve is the inability to grip paper between the fingers (Card Test) with ulnar claw hand deformity. The ulnar nerve injury can be characterized by flattening of medial border of forearm, loss of sensation at distal interphalangeal joints of 4th and 5th digit, loss of hypothenar eminence, loss of adduction of thumb, loss of abduction of fingers, clawing of 4th and 5th digits, and sensory, trophic and vasomotor changes.

 

 

Card Test (Palmar interossei – Loss of Adduction)

 

 

Ulnar Claw Hand Deformity

 

Option D. Posterior Interosseous Nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve, The deep branch of the radial nerve dives into the posterior forearm through the heads of the supinator to emerge as the posterior interosseous nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve supplies motor innervation to the posterior forearm. Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome is a compressive neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve which innervates the extensor compartment of the forearm. It usually has an insidious onset, often presenting with weakness in finger and thumb extension. However, there is preservation in wrist extension due to the radial nerve innervated extensor carpi radialis longus. It is often self-limiting and resolves with conservative measures. However, symptoms that are refractory to non-operative treatment may require surgical decompression. Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome can be present in Monteggia fractures or radial head fracture-dislocations. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnar is weakness. Depending on injury severity, there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In case of supracondylar humerus fracture, presenting with an inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb, without any sensory deficit, the nerve most commonly injured is the anterior interosseous nerve, a terminal branch of the median nerve.

questions.text: A patient came to be emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed reduction

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP

 

  • The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. 
  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed.
    • The occupant of the car is thrown forwards and his knee strikes against the dashboard. 
    • The axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction.
    • The force is transmitted up the femoral shaft, resulting in posterior dislocation of the hip. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

  • Radiological features: 
    • The femoral head is out of the acetabulum. 

 

 

  • The thigh is internally rotated so that the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken.

 

  • Treatment:
    • In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. 
    • Closed reduction is the primary and most urgent step in the management of an acute traumatic hip dislocation without associated contraindications. 
    • The sooner the reduction, the lower the risk of complications like AVN. 
    • Open reduction may be required in cases where:
      • Closed reduction fails, usually in those presenting late
      • If there is intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction
      • If the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Such a fragment makes the hip unstable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open reduction. Open reduction is done when closed reduction fails, usually in patients presenting late OR if there is an intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction OR if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight bearing part of the acetabulum. Since the question states "No associated fractures are seen," and it's an acute presentation, open reduction is not the first line.

 

Option C. NCCT pelvis: A CT scan is very useful after closed reduction to check for concentric reduction, identify any occult fractures not seen on plain X-rays (especially small intra-articular fragments or acetabular wall fractures), and assess for incarceration of fragments. However, it is not the immediate next step before reduction in an uncomplicated dislocation, as delaying reduction to get a CT increases the risk of AVN. The priority is to reduce the hip.

 

Option D. Arthroplasty. Hip replacement surgery can be considered if optimal stability is not achieved with reduction and fixation of the associated injuries. It is a definitive surgical procedure, usually performed for severe arthritis or irreparable damage. It is definitely not the immediate next step for an acute hip dislocation in a patient who likely has no pre-existing severe joint disease and no associated fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text: Identify the structure pointed in the anatomical snuffbox. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Option C) 

 

  • The marked muscle in the anatomical snuffbox is the extensor pollicis longus. 
  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is a long muscle located at the deep layer with extensor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, and supinator muscle in the posterior compartment of the forearm. 
  • It originates from the mid-third of the ulna, and interosseous membrane then courses down to the distal phalanx of the thumb. 
  • Though it is situated at the forearm, but it is classified as part of the extrinsic muscles of the hand as its function is seen in thumb movement.

 

ANATOMICAL SNUFFBOX

 

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the dorsum of the hand. 
  • It is formed by three tendons of the muscles of the thumb i.e., abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus. 
  • It is a clinically significant area due to the structures it contains, including the radial artery and the scaphoid bone. 
  • Components of anatomical snuffbox are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus (APL) is one of the extrinsic muscles of the hand. Its major function is to abduct the thumb at the wrist. Its tendon forms the anterior border of the anatomical snuffbox.

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) belongs to the deep group of the posterior fascial compartment of the forearm. It is a part of the lateral border of the anatomical snuffbox. This muscle extends the thumb at the MCP and CMC joints. It is also a mild abductor of the thumb.

 

 

Option D. Cephalic vein: The cephalic vein arises as a convergence of superficial veins on the dorsum of the hand in the anatomical snuffbox. From there it runs along the surface just above the radial styloid process. Just beneath the clavicle, the cephalic vein drains into the axillary vein, which bends downwards towards the heart.

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

  • The marked muscle tendon the given image is of the extensor pollicis longus in the anatomical snuffbox. 
  • It forms the medial boundary of the snuffbox and functions to extend the thumb.

questions.text: Match the following tumours with their treatment choices: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d

 

 

1. GIANT CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Radiological features: Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with  hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

2. OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic  bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
       
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.
       

3. SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone.
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%.
  • The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

4. OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • The proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive. A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
       
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve. If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Klumpke’s palsy?(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Claw hand

 

  • Klumpke’s palsy is the lower brachial plexus injury involving C8 and T1 nerve roots.
  • It is less common, but more severe.
  • It involves weakness of wrist and finger flexors and the intrinsic hand muscles.
  • Sensation is lost on ulnar side of the forearm.
  • There may also be vasomotor impairment and unilateral Horner’s syndrome.
  • Claw hand deformity is the usual outcome.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrist drop. The radial nerve is responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits. Consequently, injury to the radial nerve results in the inability to properly utilize these extensor muscles. As a result, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position. This is known as wrist drop.

 

 

Option B. Ape thumb deformity. Ape thumb deformity is a condition in which the thumb is permanently rotated and adducted, resulting in a loss of its opposable function. This deformity is caused by damage to the distal median nerve, which supplies the muscles that control the thumb. The thumb may also experience limited flexion and extension.

 

 

Option D. Porter’s tip deformity. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (mainly C5, partially C6) causes Erb's Paralysis. This causes paralysis of biceps, deltoid, brachialis and brachioradialis mainly; and supraspinatus, infraspinatus, supinator partially. The muscle paralysis causes the arm to hang by the side in adduction and medial rotation with forearm extended and pronated. This deformity is called as “policeman’s tip” or “porter’s tip hand”.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic deformity of Klumpke’s palsy is Claw hand due to paralysis of intrinsic hand muscles and weakness of wrist and finger flexors.

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign is characteristic of:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simple bone cyst

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Also known as unicameral bone cyst.
  • It affects children in the first and second decade.
  • The lesions are most active during skeletal growth and usually heal spontaneously at maturity.
  • They arise in the metaphysis and are central or medullary.
  • The proximal humerus and proximal femur are common sites.
  • It is not a tumor.
  • The condition is usually asymptomatic, unless discovered after a pathological fracture or as an incidental finding on X-ray.
  • An SBC contains serous or serosanguinous fluid.
  • Plain radiographs reveal a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline.
  • Occasionally (20%), a thinned cortical fragment fractures and falls into the base of the lesion confirming its empty cystic nature. This, ‘Fallen Fragment’ sign, is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst.
  • Bone fragment may also hinge around and move with fluid – ‘Trap Door sign’
  • Unicameral bone cysts are classified as active when they are within 1 cm of the physis and latent when they are closer to the diaphysis.
  • Small, asymptomatic lesions in the upper extremities can be treated with observation with serial plain radiographs.
  • Larger lesions (lesions at risk for pathological fracture), symptomatic lesions, and lesions in the lower extremities are usually are treated with curettage (with or without bone grafting or internal fixation) or aspiration and injection (often using steroids, bone marrow aspirate, demineralized bone matrix, or sclerosant).

 

 

A. Unicameral or simple bone cyst; B. Fallen fragment (leaf) sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aneurysmal bone cyst. Aneurysmal bone cysts are locally destructive, blood-filled reactive lesions of bone and are not considered to be true neoplasms. Most commonly involves the lower limbs. Vertebral lesions (15-20%) are located in the posterior elements.

 

 

Radiographs reveal an expansile lytic lesion that elevates the periosteum, but remains contained by a thin shell of cortical bone. It can have well-defined margins or a permeative appearance that mimics a malignancy. It is most often eccentrically located in the metaphysis. When differentiating between a unicameral and aneurysmal bone cyst using MRI, the presence of a double-density fluid level and intralesional septations usually indicates an aneurysmal bone cyst.

 

 

Double-density fluid level on MRI

 

Aneurysmal bone cysts are treated with extended curettage and grafting. Lesions in the spine or pelvis can be treated with preoperative embolization to minimize surgical blood loss. Low-dose irradiation is an effective method of treatment, often associated with rapid ossification; however, it is not used routinely because of the potential for malignant transformation.

 

Option C. Giant cell tumor. They typically occur in 20-40 years old patients. There is a slight female predominance. The most common location is the distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone. Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.

 

 

Treatment includes extended curettage and bone grafting; excision and replacement by vascularized bone graft/prosthetic replacement.

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fallen fragment sign is seen in simple (unicameral) bone cyst. It is a thinned cortical fragment that fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature

questions.text: An adolescent fell on an outstretched hand. For management, the doctor ties a cast as shown in the given image. Which fracture did the patient suffer from? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid fracture

 

  • Given scenario and image showing a Glass Holding Cast, most likely depicts a Scaphoid Fracture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. It is an extra-articular fracture of lower end of radius at its cortico-cancellous junction. It presents with the classical Dinner fork deformity.

 

 

 

Most Colle’s fractures can be successfully treated non-operatively and a Hand-shaking cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization in Colle’s fracture is:

 

 

Option C. Smith fracture. Smith fracture is reverse Colle’s and there is garden spade deformity due to malunion. It is an extra articular fracture of the distal radius featuring a volar displacement or angulation of the distal fragment.

 

 

The mainstay of treatment of undisplaced and stable distal radius fractures is closed reduction followed by immobilization. It is treated by close reduction and immobilization in above elbow cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension (dorsiflexion).

 

 

Option D. Galeazzi fracture. The combination of fracture of the distal third of the shaft of the radius and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (along with damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex) is called Galeazzi Fracture dislocation (the fracture of necessity). A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results. Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of undisplaced and stable scaphoid fractures, a glass-holding cast is applied.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 years

 

  • The X-ray shows 7 Carpal bones. Thus, minimum age is 5 here.
  • Also, pisiform is not seen. Hence, the age is between 5-12.
  • The best answer is 7 years as the normal age range for appearance of pisiform is 8-12 years.

 

BONE AGE

 

  • Left hand and wrist X-ray PA view – most commonly used for bone age assessment – Based on appearance of carpal bones
  • First to appear is Capitate, then in a counter-clockwise fashion except pisiform which is the last carpal bone to appear
  • Pisiform is ossified at the age of nine to 13 years as evident from different studies.
  • The appearance of ossification center of pisiform bone is one of the important evidence for estimating age among young children between nine to 13 years.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.

questions.text: Patient had a fall on Outstretched hand. He presented with Fracture and displacement of Base of 1st metacarpal. This fracture is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bennet’s fracture 

 

  • A Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone, which is associated with displacement due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle. 

 

 

  • This type of fracture typically occurs when a person falls on an outstretched hand (FOOSH injury). 
  • The mechanism of injury and the specific displacement due to muscle pull are characteristic of Bennett's fracture.
  • The shaft of the metacarpal is laterally dislocated by the unopposedpull of the abductor pollicis longus. 
  • The medial projection of the metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches remains in place. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scaphoid fracture: A scaphoid fracture is common in young adults after a fall on an outstretched hand, but it involves the scaphoid bone in the wrist, not the base of the first metacarpal.

 

 

Option C. Rolando fracture: This is also an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal (T or Y) but involves comminution without displacement.

 

 

Option D. Colles fracture: A Colles' fracture is a distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement, commonly seen in older adults after a fall on an outstretched hand, but it does not involve the first metacarpal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal with displacement due to muscle pull, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

 

MCCUNE ALBRIGHT SYNDROME

 

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bones involved)
  • Precocious puberty (endocrine abnormalities)
  • Cutaneous Pigmentation (café Au lait: coffee-colored spots)
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” bor- ders), as opposed to the smoothly marginated borders (“coast of California”) of the spots seen in neurofibromatosis.
  • Surgical treatment by curettage + bone grafting is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is the idiopathic destruction of histiocytes. The disease has characteristics of both an abnormal reactive process and a neoplastic process. It may present initially as a rash, and can disseminate and involve bone marrow, lungs, liver, spleen, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and the pituitary gland. Histologically, the primary lesion is granulomatous with an influx of eosinophils, macrophages, T cells and multinucleated cells. The Birbeck granule is the microscopic hallmark of the disorder but may not be seen in lesions of the spleen, liver, and GI tract. The rash may be distinguished by the presence of petechiae, bloody crusting, or firmly indurated nodules. Bony involvement occurs in 78% patients. Solitary osseous lesions are incidentally found and may include the skull, hip/pelvis, femur, or ribs. This bony involvement may produce bone pain. In long bones, endosteal scalloping may be responsible for a “budding appearance”.

 

 

Endosteal scalloping presenting as budding appearance

 

Option C. Neuroma with bone involvement. Morton's neuroma is one of the most common pain syndromes affecting the forefoot. It is characterized by tenderness and burning pain in the plantar surface of the forefoot, with painful paresthesias in the two affected toes. This pain syndrome is caused by perineural fibrosis of the interdigital nerves. Although the nerves between the third and fourth toes are affected most commonly, the second and third toes and, rarely, the fourth and fifth toes can be affected as well. Patients may feel like they are walking with a stone in the shoe. The pain worsens with prolonged standing or walking for long distances and is exacerbated by poorly fitting or improperly padded shoes. Morton's neuroma is associated with wearing tight, narrow-toed shoes. On physical examination, pain can be reproduced by firmly squeezing the 2 metatarsal heads together with one hand while placing firm pressure on the interdigital space with the other hand. This maneuver is known as the Mulder sign. The patient exhibits an antalgic gait in an effort to reduce weight bearing during walking.

 

 

Option D. Papillary carcinoma of thyroid. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is an epithelial malignancy showing follicular cell differentiation and nuclear features. It is the most frequent thyroid neoplasm. The tumor usually appears as an irregular solid mass. One key feature is the ability to invade adjacent structures like lymphatics. About 10% patients may present with metastatic disease at initial presentation. It usually presents as an asymptomatic thyroid mass with or without enlargement of regional (cervical) lymph nodes. Hoarseness and dysphagia occur in approximately 20% cases, signaling recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement with vocal cord paralysis or tracheal compression. Nodal metastases in the lateral neck are reported in 27% patients. The examination reveals a painless hard lesion of less than 5 cm. The mass is often fixed and has irregular borders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots.
  • Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome.

questions.text: 3-point bony relationship is maintained in which fracture?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

THREE POINT BONY LANDMARKS IN ELBOW

 

  • Tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and olecranon
  • Form isosceles triangle with elbow in 90° flexion
  • Lie transversely in straight line in elbow extension

 

 

  • Three-point bony relationship is not disturbed in fracture supracondylar humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.
  • With disturbed (increased) intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture lateral epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture medial epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture intercondylar humerus.
  • With maintained intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture olecranon (i.e. upper end ulna)
    • Elbow dislocation (classical example)
  • Waeak posterior capsule may disrupt three-point bony relation by promoting subluxation or dislocations of elbow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation. In elbow dislocation, the intercondylar distance is maintained but the three-point bony relationship is disturbed.

 

Option C. Intercondylar humerus fracture. In this fracture, the intercondylar distance is disturbed i.e., increased, so is the three-point bony relationship.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.

questions.text:
An orthopedic surgeon plans to treat a Colle’s fracture. What are the steps involved in applying a cast for the same?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Palmar flexion
  2. Traction
  3. Ulnar deviation
  4. Application of plaster of Paris
questions.solution:
Ans. C) II, I, III, IV

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Fracture of the distal radius, commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture, is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely  to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
    • The cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization is:

 

 

  • Displaced fractures should undergo an attempt at closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint acutely.
  • Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fail to meet acceptable alignment criteria.
  • Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous  pinning, external fixation, and open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).
  • Technique of closed manipulation:
    • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia.
    •  The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was ‘shaking hands’.

 

 

 

  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together.
  • This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow.
  • The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.
  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.
  • A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steps of cast application in Colles fracture are:

 

Traction

↓

Palmar flexion

↓

Ulnar deviation

↓

Application of plaster of Paris

questions.text: Which HLA is associated with Reiter’s syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HLA B27

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS

 

  • Reactive arthritis (ReA) is inflammatory arthritis that manifests after several days to weeks after a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection.
  • It is also described as a classic triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. However, a majority of patients do not present with the classic triad.
  • It is known to be triggered by a bacterial infection, particularly of the genitourinary (Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhea, Mycoplasma hominis, and Ureaplasma urealyticum) or gastrointestinal (GI) tract (Salmonella enteritidis, Shigella flexneri, and S. disenteriae, Yersinia enterocolitica, Campylobacter jejuni, Clostridium difficile).
  • The incidence is about 2-4% after a urogenital infection, mainly with Chlamydia trachomatis, and varies from 0-15% after gastrointestinal infections with Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or Yersinia.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Reactive arthritis is an immune-mediated syndrome triggered by a recent infection.
    • It is hypothesized that T lymphocytes are induced by bacterial fragments such as lipopolysaccharide and nucleic acids when invasive bacteria reach the systemic circulation.
    • These activated cytotoxic-T cells attack the synovium and other self-antigens through molecular mimicry.
    • It is believed that anti-bacterial cytokine response is also impaired in reactive arthritis, resulting in decreased bacteria elimination.
    • The prevalence of HLA-B27 in reactive arthritis is estimated at 30-50% in patients with reactive arthritis.
    • HLA-B27 should not be used as a diagnostic tool for diagnosing acute ReA.
    • The presence of HLA-B27 is believed to potentiate reactive arthritis by presenting bacterial antigens to T cells, altering the self-tolerance of the host immune system, increasing tumor necrosis factor-alpha production, promoting the invasion of microbes in the gut, and delaying clearance of causative organisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. HLA DR3: This allele is more commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus, rather than with reactive arthritis.

 

Option. C. HLA DR4: This allele is most notably associated with rheumatoid arthritis, especially in individuals who have severe disease forms.

 

Option. D. HLA DQ8: This HLA subtype is also more commonly associated with type 1 diabetes and not typically linked with reactive arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HLA-B27 is strongly associated with reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) and other spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis.
  • Approximately 75-80% of patients with reactive arthritis test positive for HLA-B27.
  • But it should not be used as a diagnostic tool for acute ReA.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. DEXA
  2. Bone scan
  3. Quantitative CT
  4. Chemical analysis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, IV are correct

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture.
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A bone scan helps to examine any irregularities in the bone. Sometimes, these bone irregularities may indicate either infection or cancer disease. In addition, it can also help to detect arthritis and bone fractures.

  • Chemical analysis test will not show any diagnostic change because the serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal in osteoporosis. The problem with osteoporosis is of bone quality and not its chemical makeup.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage – lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Investigations:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aneurysmal bone cyst. Aneurysmal bone cysts are locally destructive, blood-filled reactive lesions of bone and are not considered to be true neoplasms. Most commonly involves the lower limbs. Vertebral lesions, accounting for 15-20% of these entities, are located in the posterior elements. Radiographs reveal an expansile lytic lesion that elevates the periosteum, but remains contained by a thin shell of cortical bone. An aneurysmal bone cyst can have well-defined margins or a permeative appearance that mimics a malignancy. It is most often eccentrically located in the metaphysis. When differentiating between a unicameral and aneurysmal bone cyst using MRI, the presence of a double-density fluid level and intralesional septations usually indicates an aneurysmal bone cyst. Aneurysmal bone cysts are treated with extended curettage and grafting with a bone graft. Low-dose irradiation is effective; however, it is not used routinely because of the potential for malignant transformation.

 

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. It is highly radio-resistant and ideally treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Osteoblastoma. Osteoblastoma is an uncommon benign bone-forming neoplasm. Osteoblastoma commonly arises in the posterior elements of the spine and the sacrum. Other common locations include the mandible and long tubular bones (lower > upper extremities), where it is usually observed in the metadiaphysis. It affects mainly adolescents and young adults (mean age, 20 years) with a male predominance (2.5 to 1). The more aggressive forms are generally seen in slightly older patients, with a mean age of 33 years. Osteoblastoma less commonly involves the tarsal bones (talus and calcaneum). Like osteoid osteoma, osteoblastoma can be cortical, medullary, or rarely periosteal in a bone location. Like osteoid osteomas, osteoblastoma demonstrates marked new bone formation, although this process is generally more exuberant in osteoblastoma, which also tends to be more vascularized lesions. The nidus within osteoblastoma tends toward less organized osteoid and trabecular bone, less abundant nerve fibers, and lacks prostaglandins. They usually show aggressive behaviour with extensive uncontrollable local recurrence. Malignant transformation and metastatic diseases have been reported with osteoblastoma. On imaging, osteoblastoma lesions are most often radiolucent, round to oval, with well-defined margins and reactive sclerosis. Blown-out expansile lesion mimicking an aneurysmal bone cyst is appreciated in lesions of the axial skeleton.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows a Giant Cell Tumor of the distal end of radius.

questions.text: In the fracture seen in the X-ray below, what is the most commonly expected vascular injury?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brachial artery

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
  • Fracture supracondylar humerus is:
    • Most common fracture associated with vascular injury.
    • Most common fracture to involve brachial artery (10% cases).
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemia and compartment syndrome in children.
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemic contracture.
    • Non-union is unknown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radial artery. It can be associated with the fracture of the distal radius.

 

Option C. Ulnar artery. It can be associated with the comminuted fracture of the distal radius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar humerus fracture which is mostly associated with the brachial artery injury.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Distal pole of scaphoid is the most common carpal bone to undergo avascular necrosis.

 

Reason: Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 
  • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 
  • Middle third (waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.
  • Salient Features:
    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 
    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.
  • Complication: Non-union > Avascular necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. 
  • This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid is retrograde, from its distal end to its proximal end. 
  • At the proximal end, the blood supply diminishes. 
  • This accounts for increased chances of avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment when the proximal pole of the scaphoid is fractured.

questions.text: Which nerve seems to be damaged in the given picture? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial nerve

 

RADIAL NERVE

 

  • It is usually injured in fractures of shaft humerus, injection palsy, Saturday night palsy and Crutch palsy.
  • There is sensory loss in area supplied posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • Wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost (i.e. wrist, thumb and finger drops).

 

Types of Radial Nerve Lesion

 

  1. Very high (i.e. above spiral groove): there is Total palsy, i.e. Elbow, wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost. There is loss of sensation over dorsum of 1st web space.
  2. High (i.e. between spiral groove and lateral epicondyle): Elbow extension is spared. Brachioradialis is involved. Wrist, thumb, finger extension and sensation over dorsum of 1st web space are lost.
  3. Low (i.e. the elbow): Elbow and wrist extension are spared. Thumb, finger extension and sensation over dorsum of 1st web space are lost.
  4. Posterior interosseous nerve palsy (no Sensory deficit): Elbow and wrist joint extension, and sensations are spared. There is loss of MCP joint extension, i.e. thumb and finger drop.

 

 

  • The loss of synergic action between wrist flexors and extensors causes excessive and unwanted wrist flexion. This can be observed in a simple gripping task or asking the individual to make a fist. Both tasks will be difficult to complete as movement will be ineffective.
  • The hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve. In ulnar nerve injury, there is weakness of ulnar deviation & wrist flexion, atrophy of hypothenar eminence, weakness of palmar interossei (positive card test), weakness of finger adduction (Wartenberg’s sign), paralysis of adductor pollicis (positive froment’s sign), weak abduction of middle finger due to weak dorsal interossei (positive igawa’s test). The characteristic deformity seen is Ulnar claw hand i.e., hyperextension of MCP joint & flexion of IP joint.

 

 

 

 

 

Option C. Axillary nerve. The axillary nerve is injured in the fracture of surgical neck of humerus, anterior & inferior shoulder dislocation, & intramuscular injections. This causes deltoid muscle palsy; loss of rounded shoulder contour, giving shoulder a flattened appearance & producing a hollow inferior to acromion. 15-90⁰ of shoulder abduction becomes weak, and there is teres minor palsy also.

 

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Musculocutaneous nerve supplies coracobrachialis, the biceps brachii and the brachialis, and is continued into the forearm as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm. In its injury, there is loss of flexion of elbow, supination of forearm and sensory loss on lateral aspect of forearm. It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radial nerve injury is associated with wrist drop i.e., loss of wrist, thumb and fingers of the affected hand, as shown in the image in the question.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chance fracture

 

The image presented shows a spine injury, and based on the clinical scenario (a patient presenting after an RTA or road traffic accident), the fracture pattern described fits that of a Chance fracture. A Chance fracture, also known as a flexion-distraction injury or seatbelt fracture, typically occurs due to high-force flexion injuries, such as in a car accident where a seatbelt restrains the lower body while the upper body moves forward.
