This type of fracture involves a horizontal break extending through all three spinal columns (anterior, middle, and posterior)

 

The Chance fracture goes from anterior to posterior, involving all three columns, which is a hallmark feature of this injury. The description matches the flexion-distraction mechanism associated with this fracture.

 

Additional Information

 

Common spine fractures:

 

  1. Jefferson fracture:
    • Also called a ring fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra).
    • Mnemonic: JAT.
  2. Hangman's fracture:
    • Fracture through the interarticularis of the C2 vertebra, causing a slip of C2 over C3 (spondylolisthesis).
    • Mnemonic: H2 (Hangman’s fracture, C2 vertebra).
  3. Whiplash injury:
    • Occurs due to hyperextension followed by flexion (e.g., in a high-speed vehicle accident where the vehicle suddenly stops).
    • Resembles the motion of a whiplash.
  4. Wedge fracture:
    • The anterior height of the vertebral body is lowered while the posterior height remains normal.
  5. Burst fracture:
    • Involves damage to the anterior, middle, and posterior columns of the vertebra.
    • The vertebral body is damaged, involving both the anterior and middle columns.
    • Atlas (Jefferson) fracture is also considered a burst fracture.
  6. Chance Fracture:
    • The force moves from anterior to posterior, going all the way to the spinous process.
    • Involves flexion of the body with a distraction force.
    • Also known as jackknife or seatbelt fracture.
  7. Hinge fracture: A fracture where the skull base is divided into two halves: anterior and posterior.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burst fracture: A burst fracture involves damage to the anterior and middle columns of the vertebra, with fragments spreading outwards. While a burst fracture may result from high-energy trauma, the image and clinical description provided in this question are more characteristic of a Chance fracture. The distribution of injury in a burst fracture does not typically extend through all three columns.

 

Option C. Compression fracture: Compression fractures generally affect the anterior part of the vertebra, causing a wedge-shaped deformity, but they do not involve the middle and posterior columns like the Chance fracture. These fractures are often seen in patients with osteoporosis rather than as a result of high-energy trauma.

 

Option D. Fracture of spinous process: A fracture of the spinous process (such as a Clay-shoveler's fracture) usually involves a break in the posterior part of the vertebra only and does not involve the anterior or middle columns. This type of fracture typically occurs from direct trauma or forceful flexion but doesn't match the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.

choices.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.
Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine. Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss. These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non vertebral fractures.
  • Prolonged used of Bisphosphonates has been reported with increased incidence of fractures of proximal femur. Hence, a patient on Bisphosphonates with hip pain requires X-rays to evaluate and diagnose these fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time. Teriparatide is a recombinant fragment of human parathyroid hormone. To preserve the increments of BMD acquired with teriparatide, therapy with an antiresorptive agent (e.g., bisphosphonates) should restart after teriparatide discontinuation. Bisphosphonates help retain BMD gains that tend to regress after cessation of teriparatide. Concomitant use with teriparatide is to be avoided because they may blunt its anabolic effect.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day. 1200 mg of calcium (total of diet and supplement) and 800 international units of vitamin D daily for postmenopausal osteoporosis are recommended.

 

Option D. Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation is a necessary adjunct to all forms of anti-osteoporotic therapies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Humerus

 

  • The image shows fracture of the upper end of humerus.

 

PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Approximately 40% of metaphyseal proximal humerus fractures are non- or minimally displaced and more commonly require operative treatment as compared to epiphyseal fractures.
  • The peak of these fractures occurs between ages of 10-14 and again at 80-84 years with males more affected.
  • Proximal humerus fractures most often occur upon falling backwards onto an outstretched hand with an extended elbow and externally rotated shoulder or through direct traumatic impact to the shoulder. 
  • The Neer-Horowitz system is the most widely used classification system for proximal humerus fractures in children and is graded by severity of displacement.

 

 

  • On examination, there may be swelling, tenderness, visible deformity, and unwillingness to move the shoulder by holding the arm close to the body.
  • Associated injuries to the brachial plexus, clavicle, and scapula should not be missed.
  • Standard radiographs of the shoulder including AP, and axillary views are generally sufficient to characterize the fracture morphology.
  • The majority of proximal humerus fractures in children can be treated successfully with non-operative management due to the immense remodelling potential of the physis.
  • Neer-Horowitz grade I/II can be successfully treated non-operatively with immobilization in a hanging arm/shoulder spica cast and a sling for 3-4 weeks.
  • Operative treatment should be considered in Neer-Horowitz grade III and IV fractures and greater fracture angulation in older children.
  • Failure of closed reduction should be addressed with open reduction.
  • Fixation options include percutaneous pinning, intramedullary nails, cannulated screws, and plates.

 

 

  • Percutaneous pinning remains the most commonly used fixation strategy.
  • Prognosis in children are generally excellent with both non-operative and operative treatment. 
  • Complications are rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicle. The clavicle is one of the most common fractured bones in children. These heal quickly and recover fully. Injuries are usually the result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the force transmitted up the arm. A direct blow to the outer end of the clavicle can be associated with distal third injuries and acromioclavicular joint disruption. The vast majority present with pain, swelling and deformity along the line of the clavicle, and a history of a fall onto an outstretched arm. Fractures of the medial third are usually the result of high impact blunt force to the anterior chest (such as in a motor vehicle accident), and can be associated with neurovascular, pulmonary and cardiac (rare) injuries. Careful airway protection and neurovascular assessment is required. Vascular assessment of the arm should also be performed as the subclavian artery runs close to the clavicle in the middle third. Standard AP with 15 degrees cephalic tilt x-ray of the clavicle will show the fracture in two planes and define displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are easily managed with a sling and analgesia.

 

 

Option C. Scapula. Scapula fractures are uncommon in children. Scapular body fractures are usually the result of high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle collisions or falls. There is a high incidence of associated injuries including other shoulder girdle fractures, rib fractures, head injury, and lung injury, such as pneumothorax or pulmonary contusion. Glenoid fractures are often due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder or a fall onto a flexed elbow with the humeral head being driven into the glenoid. The position of the arm dictates whether an anterior or posterior rim fracture occurs. Similarly, acromion fractures are usually due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder. Coracoid fractures are usually an avulsive injury resulting from pull of the acromioclavicular ligaments or the conjoint tendon. Scapulothoracic dissociation is often due to a severe traction injury. The primary symptom is often pain about the shoulder or back and difficulty with motion. Numbness or weakness may be present with a concomitant brachial plexus injury. The majority of fractures are treated non-operatively. Treatment includes immobilization for 3-4 weeks followed by pendulum exercises and protected range of motion. 

 

Option D. Ribs. Rib fracture in children is caused by a high force injury. Ribs 1-3 are the hardest to break. Ribs 4-10 are typically the most vulnerable while ribs 11-12 are more mobile and therefore, more difficult to break. Since children tend to have more elastic ribs than adults, children are less likely to sustain rib fractures. Therefore, children with rib fractures is a sign of significant trauma and should warrant an investigation of possible child abuse. The physical exam may reveal chest wall bruising, along with bony tenderness to palpitation or crepitus. For simple, isolated rib fractures, conservative treatment is usually adequate which includes appropriate analgesia, rest, and ice. The use of an incentive spirometer should be encouraged to prevent pulmonary atelectasis and splinting. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and discharging pus from right leg for 3 months. Following is the radiograph of the child. Identify the labelled structured:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Involucrum

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Presenting Complaints:
    • A chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presenting symptom.
    • The onset of sinus may be traced back to an episode of acute osteomyelitis during childhood.
    • Often sinuses heal for short periods, only to reappear with each acute exacerbation.
    • Quality of discharge varies from seropurulent to thick pus.
    • There may be a history of extrusion of small bone fragments from the sinus.
    • Pain is usually minimal but may become aggravated during acute exacerbations.  
    • Generalized symptoms of infection such as fever, etc. are present only during acute exacerbations.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices
    • Patchy sclerosis
    • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis
    • Sequestrum: Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues
    • Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum. There may be some holes in the involucrum for pus  to drain out. These holes are called cloacae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis is primarily surgical.
    • Antibiotics are useful only during acute exacerbations and during postoperative period.
    • Various surgical options are:
      • Sequestrectomy
      • Saucerisation
      • Curettage
      • Excision of an infected bone
      • Amputation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the dense sclerotic bone called the involucrum. It has some holes to drain out pus, called as cloaca.
  • Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the normal bone because there is no decalcification like the normal bone.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alendronate

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis.
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

  • Treatment:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Alendronate:
    • Alendronate is approved for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis, steroid-induced osteoporosis, and male osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate belongs to the class of bisphosphonate medications, which aids in the prevention of bone resorption and the promotion of bone density, making it a valuable treatment for osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate is an option for maintaining or increasing bone mass, whereas risedronate is preferred in men with osteoporosis.
    • It inhibit bone resorption at rates 1000 times greater than the effect on bone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium and Vitamin D. They are given along with the bisphosphonates but are not the only treatment choice. Calcium is given at a dose of 1500 mg/day. Vitamin D is given at the dose of 400-800 IU per day. Initially, Vit. D deficient patients are treated with active metabolite 1,25, dihydroxy Vit D3 (short half-life 4 hours and expensive) then changing over to longer lasting and less expensive Vit D2 or D3 (t ½ up to 2½ months).

 

Option B. Hormone replacement therapy. The mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis is estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Repeat DEXA scan after 6 months. The DEXA scan is repeated after 6 months to 1 year after starting of the drug treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma):

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology:
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% malignant transformation. This is incorrect. Pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.

 

Option C. Ground glass opacity is diagnostic. This is incorrect. Ground glass opacity of the bone is seen in fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy is the treatment. This is incorrect. The mainstay of treatment of GCT is curettage and stripping of the cavity. More aggressive tumors are treated by excision and bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.
